lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a video and answer comprehension questions about playing football in the snow in Iqaluit.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Pause the video after each scene. Ask: “What are they doing?” “What’s the weather like?” Students choose answers from SB options.
stretchStrategies: Students role-play as international sports reporters, giving a 2-sentence report about sports in unusual weather (e.g., “It’s snowy in Canada. They play football in the snow.”).

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can explain how people play different sports in different countries and weather conditions.
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) Ask: “Can you play football in the snow?” Discuss how it’s possible. Students list challenges and compare with football in their country.
stretchStrategies: Students role-play as international sports reporters, giving a 2-sentence report about sports in unusual weather (e.g., “It’s snowy in Canada. They play football in the snow.”).

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can discuss and think critically about whether boys and girls play the same sports and explore why or why not.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Critical Thinking) Ask: “Do boys and girls play the same sports?” Group discussion followed by a simple agree/disagree vote with short reasoning.
stretchStrategies: Students role-play as international sports reporters, giving a 2-sentence report about sports in unusual weather (e.g., “It’s snowy in Canada. They play football in the snow.”).

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
